Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I glanced at the clock, knowing my shift would end soon. My last client, Mrs. Lee, smiled in the mirror and asked if I could trim her fringe just a bit more. She was always pleasant, but I could sense she wanted it perfect this time. As I reached for my scissors, my phone buzzed with a message from my partner: “Rough day, nothing major, just need to vent later.” I remembered the way they’d sounded this morning—tired, but hopeful I’d be home on time. My mind raced. Mrs. Lee deserved my full attention; she trusted me to get her look just right. But my partner needed me, too, even if they downplayed it. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing in—one pair of hands, two hearts to care for. I smiled at Mrs. Lee, steadying my hands, but inside, I was torn, wondering how I could possibly be enough for both of them tonight.
